s1.title: The Physics of Sound
s1.subtitle: Music begins with vibration. A string moves back and forth, pushes air, and your ear turns that into sound.

kb.p1: Sound is <vibration>vibration</vibration> traveling through air. Pluck a ukulele string and it vibrates hundreds of times per second, pushing air molecules that reach your ear as sound waves.
kb.p2: The speed of vibration is called <frequency>frequency</frequency>, measured in <hertz>Hz</hertz>. Higher frequency = higher pitch. Lower frequency = lower pitch.
kb.p3: The note A above middle C vibrates at exactly 440 Hz, an international standard adopted in 1955. Every other note in Western music is defined relative to this reference point.
kb.p4: The fretboard below shows each string position and its frequency. Click any position to hear it. Moving up the neck (higher fret numbers) shortens the string, raising the pitch.

s2.title: Pitch Perception & Cents
s2.subtitle: Humans hear pitch in ratios, not absolute values. This has consequences for how we measure and tune.

kb.p1: Going from 100 Hz to 200 Hz sounds like the same jump as going from 200 Hz to 400 Hz. Both are a doubling, and a doubling always sounds like "the same note, one octave higher."
kb.p2: We hear <ratios>ratios</ratios>, not differences. A 100 Hz gap at 200 Hz is perceptually huge; the same gap at 2000 Hz is barely noticeable. Frequency in Hz doesn't map to what we actually hear.
kb.p3: <cents>Cents</cents> fix this. One octave = 1200 cents. One semitone = 100 cents. Cents scale linearly with perceived pitch, so equal distances in cents sound like equal distances to your ear.
kb.p4: In the chart below, toggle between Linear and Log scale. On linear, frequency curves upward exponentially. On log, it straightens out. The log view matches human perception.
kb.p5: Compare two frequencies below and hear the difference in cents. 10 cents off is barely noticeable. 50 cents is clearly out of tune.

s3.title: Harmonics & Consonance
s3.subtitle: A vibrating string produces not one frequency but many. These overtones determine why some note combinations sound stable and others don't.

kb.p1: A plucked string vibrates at its <fundamental>fundamental</fundamental> frequency and at integer multiples: 2x, 3x, 4x, 5x, and so on. These additional frequencies are called <overtones>overtones</overtones>, and together they form the <harmonicSeries>harmonic series</harmonicSeries>.
kb.p2: You don't hear each overtone individually. They blend into what you perceive as the note's timbre (the reason a ukulele and a piano playing the same note sound different). But your brain does use overtones to judge whether notes work together.
kb.p3: When two notes share many overtone frequencies, you perceive <consonance>consonance</consonance>. Simple frequency ratios (2:1 for the octave, 3:2 for the fifth) produce the most overlap. Complex ratios produce <dissonance>dissonance</dissonance>.
kb.p4: Pick two notes below and compare their overtone overlap. Try C and G (a perfect fifth) versus C and C# (a minor second) to hear and see the difference.

s4.title: Intervals
s4.subtitle: The distance between two notes, measured in semitones. Intervals are how scales, chords, and melodies are constructed.

kb.p1: An interval is the distance between two notes. There are 12 possible intervals within an octave, from unison (0 semitones) to the octave (12 semitones).
kb.li1: Perfect consonances (unison, fourth, fifth, octave): stable, open
kb.p3: On a fretboard, intervals form geometric patterns. A perfect fifth always has the same shape regardless of starting note. Learn the shape once and it works everywhere.

s5.title: Scales
s5.subtitle: Out of 12 chromatic notes, a scale selects the subset that defines a piece's tonal character.

kb.p1: A <scale>scale</scale> picks a subset of the 12 chromatic notes that work together. Most Western scales use 7 notes, leaving 5 out. The pattern of whole steps and half steps between them defines the character.
kb.p2: The major scale follows W-W-H-W-W-W-H. It sounds bright and resolved. The minor scale follows W-H-W-W-H-W-W. Same notes rearranged from a different starting point, but the mood shifts completely.
kb.p3: A scale sets the palette for a piece of music. Melodies and chords are typically drawn from the notes of the current scale.

s6.title: Chords
s6.subtitle: Three or more notes played simultaneously. Built by stacking intervals, mostly thirds.

kb.p1: A <chord>chord</chord> is built by stacking intervals. The simplest chord, a <triad>triad</triad>, uses the 1st, 3rd, and 5th notes of a scale.
kb.p2: Major triad = root + major 3rd (4 semitones) + perfect 5th (7 semitones). Minor triad = root + minor 3rd (3 semitones) + perfect 5th (7 semitones). The difference between major and minor is one semitone on the third.
kb.p3: Adding more notes creates richer chords: 7ths add the 7th scale degree, sus chords replace the 3rd with a 2nd or 4th, and extended chords (9th, 11th, 13th) stack additional thirds.
kb.p4: A <voicing>voicing</voicing> is how a chord's notes are distributed across the strings. The same C major chord has many possible voicings, each with a different character.

s7.title: Keys & The Circle of Fifths
s7.subtitle: A key is a scale plus its home chord. The circle of fifths maps how all 12 keys relate.

kb.p1: A <key>key</key> is a scale plus its <tonic>tonic</tonic> (home chord). "In the key of C major" means: the C major scale provides the notes, and C is home.
kb.p2: The circle of fifths arranges all 12 keys so that neighbors are a perfect fifth apart. Adjacent keys share 6 of 7 notes, making transitions between them smooth. Keys on opposite sides share very few notes.
kb.p3: Every key produces 7 <diatonic>diatonic</diatonic> chords: 3 major (I, IV, V), 3 minor (ii, iii, vi), and 1 diminished (vii°). These are the chords that belong to the key.

s8.title: Chord Progressions
s8.subtitle: Chords in sequence create harmonic motion: tension, resolution, surprise. The order matters as much as the chords themselves.

kb.p1: A <progression>chord progression</progression> is a sequence of chords that creates harmonic motion. Each chord has a <harmonicFunction>harmonic function</harmonicFunction>:
kb.p2: I-IV-V-I is the basic pattern: home, depart, tension, resolve. The V-to-I resolution is the strongest pull in Western harmony, the cadence.
kb.p3: I-V-vi-IV is probably the most common progression in modern pop: "Let It Be," "Someone Like You," "No Woman, No Cry." It appears across decades and genres because the tension-resolution cycle it creates is consistently effective.
kb.p4: Theory describes which chords can follow each other. The data below shows what actually happens. Pick a chord and see the probability distribution of what comes next, computed from 660,000 real progressions.

s9.title: The Creative Toolset
s9.subtitle: Composition and analysis tools backed by a statistical model trained on 660,000 real songs across 9 genres.

kb.p1: The tools below combine music theory with a statistical model trained on the Chordonomicon dataset: 660,000 chord progressions across 9 genres (pop, rock, country, punk, alternative, pop rock, rap, metal, soul).
kb.p2: Recommendations reflect real usage. When the model suggests G after C with 36% probability in pop, that's the actual frequency in the dataset. Theory explains why a transition works; the data shows how often it actually occurs.

progressionExplorer.title: Progression Explorer
progressionExplorer.description: Build chord progressions with genre-aware recommendations. Up to 5 parallel paths, 9 genres, voicing selection, and audio playback.

melodyExplorer.title: Melody Explorer
melodyExplorer.description: Generate melodies in 4 styles (smooth, melodic, angular, arpeggiated) across any key and scale. Compare paths, edit individual notes, or practice on the fretboard.

dataInsights.title: Data Insights: What 660,000 Songs Tell Us
dataInsights.description: Visualizations drawn from 667,858 chord progressions and 51 million chord occurrences.
dataInsights.chordFrequency: Chord usage follows a power law: the top 10 chords account for most occurrences in any genre, while thousands of others appear rarely. The most-used chords (G, C, D, A, E) are also the easiest open shapes on guitar, which is not a coincidence.
dataInsights.genreFingerprints: Each genre has a distinct harmonic profile. Pop is predictable and major-heavy. Metal is diverse with chromatic chords. Soul leans on extensions and dominant harmony. The radar chart below makes these differences visible.
dataInsights.transitionMatrix: The full transition matrix: for every chord pair, how often does one follow the other? The matrix is asymmetric (C goes to G far more often than G goes to C). Color intensity is probability. Click any cell to hear the transition.
dataInsights.gCentric: In the graph below, chords are positioned by transition strength: chords that frequently follow each other cluster together. In guitar-based genres, G, C, and D consistently land at the center. The layout is computed from the data, not manually arranged.
